abstracts.cdata!:
The Education Innovation Project for the
            Russian Federation had the following ratings: the outcome
            was satisfactory, the sustainability was highly likely, the
            institutional development impact was substantial, and the
            Bank and borrower performance were both satisfactory.
            Lessons learned: Consistent staffing patterns from the Bank
            and Client sides facilitates good implementation. Building
            capacity in implementing agencies whether at Federal or
            local level is crucial to sustainability. Bottom Up
            approaches to institutionalizing change do work - a limited
            amount of funding can facilitate significant change but
            should be supported also by policy dialogue. Flexibility in
            adapting project activities when necessary is vital when
            working in a rapidly changing environment. Not all
            activities will be sustainable - transitioning to a free
            market often means that change becomes more, not less rapid.
            When project activities are decentralized to regional levels
            of government or to institutions, they become more difficult
            to monitor, and more susceptible to swings in local
            priorities and funding. A success of the project was to
            demonstrate that lending directly to institutions is a
            viable way to encourage change. Designing projects for large
            countries, where the Bank financing can only provide
            catalytic impetus is a significant challenge and the
            mechanisms piloted by this program should be utilized elsewhere.
